qas.question: What alterations did Crane make to secure commercial publication?

answers.text: remove profanity, but he also made stylistic revisions

qas.question: What was Bower's first step in editing multiple works into a single product?

answers.text: to preserve the stylistic and literary changes of 1896

qas.question: What was Bower's second step in editing multiple works into a single product?

answers.text: to revert to the 1893 readings where he believed that Crane was fulfilling the publisher's intention rather than his own

qas.question: What was one of the criticisms Bowers faced after editing Maggie?

answers.text: to preserve the stylistic and literary changes of 1896,

qas.question: What was the second step Bowers took in editing a single work with two versions?

answers.text: to revert to the 1893 readings where he believed that Crane was fulfilling the publisher's intention

qas.question: What changes were made for the commercial publication of Maggie?

answers.text: to remove profanity, but he also made stylistic revisions

qas.question: What changes did Maggie make to secure commercial publication?

plausible_answers.text: preserve the stylistic and literary changes

qas.question: What was Bower's final step in editing a single work into multiple versions?

context: Bowers confronted a similar problem in his edition of Maggie. Crane originally printed the novel privately in <a8_0><b10_0><b12_0>1893<b12_0/><b10_0/><a8_0/>. To secure commercial publication in <a4_0>1896<a4_0/>, Crane agreed <a7_0>to <a0_0><b9_0>remove profanity<b9_0/>, but he also made stylistic revisions<a7_0/><a0_0/>. Bowers's approach was <a1_0><a5_0>to <b11_0>preserve the stylistic and literary changes<b11_0/> of <b13_0>1896<b13_0/><a1_0/>,<a5_0/> but <a2_0><a6_0>to revert to the 1893 readings where he believed that Crane was fulfilling the publisher's intention<a6_0/> rather than his own<a2_0/>. There were, however, intermediate cases that could reasonably have been attributed to either intention, and some of Bowers's choices came under fire – both as to <a3_0>his judgment<a3_0/>, and as to the wisdom of conflating readings from the two different versions of Maggie.
